results.name: Decimal expansion of the sum of the reciprocals of the palindromic numbers A002113.
comment: The sum using all palindromic numbers < 10^8 is 3.37000183240... Extrapolating using Wynn's epsilon method gives a value near 3.37018... - _Eric W. Weisstein_, May 14 2006
link: Joseph Myers, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1001

Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Palindromic Number.
mathematica: NextPalindrome[n_] := Block[{l = Floor[ Log[10, n] + 1], idn = IntegerDigits@ n}, If[ Union@ idn == {9}, Return[n + 2], If[l < 2, Return[n + 1], If[ FromDigits[ Reverse[ Take[ idn, Ceiling[l/2]]]] > FromDigits[ Take[idn, -Ceiling[l/2]]], FromDigits[Join[Take[idn, Ceiling[l/2]], Reverse[Take[idn, Floor[l/2]]]]], idfhn = FromDigits[Take[idn, Ceiling[l/2]]] + 1; idp = FromDigits[ Join[ IntegerDigits@ idfhn, Drop[ Reverse[ IntegerDigits@ idfhn], Mod[l, 2]]]]]]]]; pal = 1; sm = 0; Do[ While[pal < 10^n + 1, sm = N[sm + 1/pal, 128]; pal = NextPalindrome@ pal]; Print[{n, sm}], {n, 0, 17}] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Oct 20 2010 *)
